awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling the Vulnerability of Mobile Home Parks to Disaster: A Longitudinal Study of Affordable Housing Loss After Hurricane Harvey
awd_abstract_narration:
Hundreds of mobile home parks located in diverse geographic, political, and demographic parts of the Houston area were flooded during Hurricane Harvey. This project examines the damage and tracks the recovery of those parks over time using a combination of geospatial, qualitative, and quantitative research methods. This research design will identify the reasons for differential damage and recovery across parks. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be new knowledge about the vulnerability of the mobile home parks to natural hazards and methods to mitigate risks. The project provides training and mentoring for a diverse group of student researchers, and its findings will be incorporated into graduate education programs. The study's methodology, modeling framework, and key findings will be made available to policy-makers and planning practitioners through a mobile home park vulnerability assessment guide. 

The study will identify and analyze factors that influence post-disaster mobile home park recovery, defined by park closure, rebuilding, housing loss, and change in assessed value. A geospatial database of all Houston mobile home parks that experienced flooding will be created to analyze exposure. It will be populated with data from a recovery survey of park owners at one and two years after Harvey and spatial, regulatory and socio-demographic information on parks. Interviews with mobile home park owners, resident leadership, and local officials, and analysis of codes and plans will be conducted in 15-20 mobile home parks strategically sampled from the study population. Indicators representing the factors that enable or impede park recovery will be tested across the study population using quantitative modeling techniques. Results will be interpreted and disseminated to provide a better understanding of vulnerability in mobile home parks, a critical though understudied component of the U.S. affordable housing supply.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to understand disaster-related impacts to manufactured home parks (commonly known as mobile home parks) in metropolitan areas affected by major hurricanes in Texas (Hurricane Harvey) and Florida (Hurricanes Michael and Irma). The project analyzed post-disaster recovery for manufactured home parks (MHPs), specifically how local plans and policies help, or hinder, recovery trajectories of MHPs, including how policies may have increased vulnerability of the parks to disaster risks.

To understand the impacts of Hurricanes Harvey, Michael and Irma on MHPs, our team created a novel geodatabase of manufactured home park locations in the metropolitan statistical areas impacted by these hurricanes. We used County Appraisal District (CAD) land use records in Texas and Department of Health data in Florida, which we cross-checked with national data sets on the locations of MHPs from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Reference USA business data, and a real estate website for MHPs, MHVillage. We geocoded the locations and addresses of MHPs and then visually and manually adjusted the actual boundaries of the MHP parcel(s). Our completed MHP dataset revealed significant gaps in other public data on MHPs, which undercounted and misidentified MHP parcels. We have made our dataset publicly available to other researchers for additional inquiries regarding the location, size, type, risks, and vulnerabilities of the MHPs in these regions.

To understand factors contributing the post-disaster outcomes in MHPs, we paired our MHP geodatabase with data from the American Communities Survey to analyze sociodemographic, built environment, and environmental exposure characteristics of census block groups with higher shares of MHP land compared to block groups with fewer or no MHP land. We show that MHPs are clustered near other MHPs in areas with less access to transportation and urban amenities and greater exposure to environmental hazards. We found that areas with MHPs have, on average, greater amounts of land in the 100-year floodplain. We demonstrate that the location of MHPs is associated with exclusionary land use regulations.

To further evaluate the role of land use regulations and planning in the disaster exposure and post-disaster recovery trajectories of MHPs, we collected land-use regulations from the 134 jurisdictions in the Houston MSA to pair with our geodatabase of MHP locations for that MSA. We analyze how jurisdictions shape development, expansion, or improvement of MHPs within their boundaries, and how the regulation of MHPs varies across jurisdictions. The analysis sheds light on regional housing segregation, and how existing and future manufactured home parks will likely be developed in unincorporated areas, places with less infrastructure, fewer services, and uncertain development patterns.

 Our work to date to analyze FEMA Individual Assistance claims shows manufactured home parks are more likely to be located in flood risk areas, and therefore receive more damage during heavy rain events, and that a smaller share are likely to receive the eligible amount of damage assistance payments from FEMA when compared to single family homes. Our papers analyzing manufacture home park recovery and future flood risk contribute to limited research on MHPs in the wake of disaster and may inform land use policies supporting both mitigation and recovery processes for MHPs. These analyses reveal how land use regulations and locational factors influence risk to socially vulnerable individuals and an already limited affordable housing stock. These results contribute to the growing literature on the inequitable recovery policies from natural disaster.

We maintain a website populated with findings, maps, and instructions on how to request access to our manufactured home parks database for Texas and Florida.

To generalize our findings about manufactured home park vulnerability and recovery and inform planners and policy makers on how to best reduce risk to manufactured home parks from natural hazards we have published our findings in a series of public outlets including the online blogs of the Kinder Institute, the Urban Institute, and the American Planning Association. We have also presented study findings at conferences and invited talks and have provided context expertise to media outlets reporting on manufactured housing and disasters.
